description: New versions range from ‘disruptive’ models like Jaquet Droz’s Rolling Stones watch to idyllic scenes from Van Cleef & Arpels.
title: Automatons Move to the Next Level
title_page: Automatons Move to the Next Level - The New York Times
maintext:
Ask some experts what an automaton is in the watch industry and their replies include: “It creates a sense of wonder.” “It’s a piece of art which is not static but moving.’’ “It doesn’t just tell the time, it creates an emotion.”
It could be a table clock like Van Cleef & Arpels’s Rêveries de Berylline, which has a flower that opens its petals to reveal a bird. It could be a wristwatch like Jaquet Droz’s The Dragon, which has the winged serpent breathe fire and flick its tail.
The one thing that is certain is that an automaton timepiece will contain elaborate and highly synchronized moving parts that create a balletic moment, all the while telling what time it is.
Examples, especially from the automaton’s glory days of the 18th century, can be found in museums. But some new ones on the scene are creating motions that horologists of the past likely never imagined.
